out_info_info: The impact of the intervention on writing traits such as sentence fluency, word choice, voice, and so on, was tested.   Outcome  It was found that statistically significant improvements were made on organisation, voice, and word choice on the 6+1 Trait Writing model. Statistically insignificant improvements were made in sentence fluency, conventions, and presentation, which were not included in the outcome reports.

out_info_ht: ['Page 93:\n[¬s]"The quantitative measures used to assess students’ self-regulatory behavior and motivational beliefs were drawn from the field of educational psychology. I selected a survey, the M otivated Strategies f o r Learning Questionnaire, or MSLQ (Pintrich & DeGroot, 1990), to measure student levels of self-regulation and motivation before and after the research intervention.[¬e]"', 'Page 98:\n[¬s]"Individual interviews were conducted post-treatment to learn about students\' attitudes and beliefs toward learning science and to determine whether their attitudes and beliefs had changed as a result o f the intervention.[¬e]"']
part_other_ht: ['Page 101:\n[¬s]"A brief interview (30 minutes) with the two teachers in the treatment group was conducted at the completion o f the unit (see Appendix J). The purpose o f this interview was to leam about teacher observations o f how students responded to the treatment. I wanted to find out whether their perceptions echoed the attitudes and reactions that students had expressed in their interviews. I was also curious about teacher responses to the intervention and wanted to know whether their participation in the research study had influenced their thinking about the role o f assessment and reflection in science learning.[¬e]"']

test_subject_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"During the training session, children in all groups were instructed to repeat aloud the names of a different set of Peabody drawings as the E[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]"presented them on each of 10 trials, and to continue repeating them until the recall signal was given. Following Hagen, Hargrave, and Ross (9), prompts were given when children neglected to rehearse or rehearsed in incorrect sequence. Children in Rehearsal Only had five additional rehearsal trials. The remaining children were, instead, initially trained for five trials in a careful looking strategy. They were told to think about how each picture looked as the E pointed to the pictures on each trial, and to keep thinking about how they looked until the signal for recall was given. In order to block overt verbal rehearsal, they were also asked to stick out their tongues during presentation and delay periods. Children in the Compare Rehearsal & Look condition were initially told that we were trying the two strategies in order to see which way of remembering produced more correct recalls. This compari\xad son was made and explained with the use of the child’s own data at the end of training.[¬e]"']

like to spend their holidays’).[¬e]"']

['Page 43:\n[¬s]"Academic Competency Assessment. All participants were asked to complete an academic competency assessment. At the onset of the study, all participants were administered four questions about their perceptions and skills in the content area of writing. The items comprising this scale included: (a) \x93In general, how much do you like writing?;\x94 (b) \x93How good do you think you are at writing?;\x94 (c) \x93How much do you like to write stories?;\x94 and (d) How much do you like being timed on writing?\x94 A sample script is located in Appendix E.[¬e]"', 'Page 44:\n[¬s]"Intervention Acceptability Assessment. All participants receiving performance feedback information were asked to complete an intervention acceptability assessment. At the conclusion of the study, students were administered three questions about their perceptions and skills in the content area of writing. The following three questions were asked: (a) \x93How much did you like being told how many words your wrote last time?;\x94 (b) \x93How much did you like being told how many words you spelled correctly last time?;\x94 and (c) \x93How much did you like being told how many sentences you had written last time?\x94 A sample script is located in Appendix G.[¬e]"']

['Page 5:\n[¬s]" The test of self-reported use of the steps in the writing strategy included five scales ranging in 10-unit intervals from 0—not at all, to 100—a whole lot. out_info_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The third dependent variable was attitude to- ward instruction. Attitude toward instruction was measured by the Shop and Laboratory Inventory developed by Curtis R. Finch (1969), which was designed to assess a student's attitude toward a specific period of instruction which had been com- pleted, i.e., hour, day, week, etc. This instrument was made up of instructionally related statements which were both negative (unfavorable) and posi- tive (favorable). The statements were randomly ordered and placed on forms with a 5-point scale ranging from strongly agree to strongly disagree. Reliability was reported by the Kuder-Richardson Formula 20 as .92 with a sample size of 170."
"The last dependent variable under consideration in this study was that of time utilized for instruc- tion. Students were required to keep a record of all time spent upon instruction and testing for each unit on a sheet located at the front of each instructional booklet.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]" Immediate cognitive achievement and delayed cognitive achievement related to the composite instructional material were assessed with the same achievement test.[¬e]"']
